• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.

in compliance.

violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• Indicate how continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206 Staff Qualification.
Section (2) A staff member must be of responsible character and suitable
Description and able to met the needs of children and families served by the
agency.
2

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation A worker of a private foster care agency, who is also a foster
parent, used his official capacity as a private agency worker to
inappropriately access the record of a foster youth that was in his
care to get updates about the case in an attempt to get the foster
youth back after requesting replacement. The worker was written
up by the private agency.
Investigation Interviews:
Director X
On 8/21/2023, I interviewed the complainant, Director X, by
telephone. Additional information was provided by Director X via
email that same day. Director X advised that she is the Director of
Wexford/Missaukee County Department of Health and Human
Services (DHHS). She reported Foster Care Worker (FCW) 3 is a
licensed foster parent with Wexford/Missaukee DHHS; and an
employee of Holy Cross Children’s Services-Mid-Michigan (Holy
Cross-MM). FCW 3 and his wife, Foster Parent B had Foster
Child A in their licensed foster home, and the couple requested
Child A’s removal. After Child A’s replacement, FCW 3 and his
wife became remorseful about the removal and FCW 3 began
accessing Foster Child A’s record as a FCW, which he is not for
this child. Director X reported their office became suspicious
because of information that FCW 3 would report about the case. It
was information FCW 3 should not have known about. Director X
recalled a telephone conversation she had with FCW 3 sometime
in mid-May of 2023. During that telephone call, FCW 3 expressed
his regrets over asking for Child A to be replaced; and wished to
have Child A moved back to his home. FCW 3 further told Director
X he learned that Child A’s mom was going to release her parental
rights and he and his wife are now hoping to adopt Child
A. Director X stated at the time of the telephone call Child A had
been out of FCW 3’s and his wife’s care for almost one month.
Child A’s mother’s plan to release her parental rights was not
public knowledge; and it was believed that FCW 3 learned that
information through him accessing MiSACWIS.
Director X said they reported the suspicions about FCW 3 to Holy
Cross-MM. Thereafter the agency requested a MISACWIS
analysis of FCW 3’s MISACWIS activity and the research showed
access to aspects of Child A’s record. Director X reported these
events were a few months back, maybe May or June of this year.
Director X reported after the MISACWIS research results, Holy
Cross-MM reported the matter was discussed with FCW 3 and
3

FCW 3 was disciplined. Holy Cross-MM did not tell her how FCW
3 was disciplined.
Chief Administrator 1
On 8/22/2023 I interviewed Holy Cross-MM Chief Administrator
(CA)1 about this allegation by telephone. CA 1 acknowledged
awareness of the allegation of inappropriate access of Child A’s
MISACWIS record by FCW 3. She reported this information was
first brought to her attention back in late May or early June of 2023
by telephone and in a subsequent meeting with
Wexford/Missaukee DHHS. CA 1 reported she thought this matter
had been dealt with. She voiced surprise by this complaint against
the agency. She confirmed that Holy Cross-MM requested
research of FCW 3’s MISACWIS activities with respect to Child
A’s case, back when the matter came to their attention. CA 1
reported when she and Supervisor 2 met with FCW 3, FCW 3
admitted to accessing Child A’s record. FCW 3 did not give a
detailed reason for his action. FCW 3 said something to the effect
of being curious about the status of Child A’s case. CA 1 reported
thereafter, FCW 3 was disciplined by written disciplinary action.
CA 1 reported outside of a coaching disciplinary action for not
following the difficulty of care approval policy, this was FCW 3’s
first written disciplinary action. She reported there was no
corrective plan for FCW 3 with the disciplinary write up. FCW 3
was advised future inappropriate actions could lead to his
termination. I requested a copy of FCW 3’s disciplinary action. A
copy has not been received.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) 3:
On 8/30/2023, I interviewed FCW 3 via TEAMS related to this
complaint. FCW 3 acknowledged awareness of the complaint
against him; and that he was Child A’s prior foster parent. He
reported him and his wife, Foster Parent B, have been licensed
foster parents with Wexford/Missaukee DHHS since March 2021.
He accused Wexford/Missaukee DHHS of making this complaint.
He reported knowing this because on 8/28/2023
Wexford/Missaukee DHHS opened a special evaluation against
his and Foster Parent B’s foster home for allegations about
confidential information being shared. He reported this
MISACWIS access matter was brought to his employer’s (Holy
Cross-MM) attention months ago by Wexford/Missaukee DHHS
and his agency director addressed it with him. He said he
admitted to doing something wrong, that he will never do it again
and he has not since.
4

FCW 3 admitted to searching MISACWIS using Child A’s name.
Using this method allowed him some access, but since he was not
the assigned worker for Child A in the MISACWIS system, he
could not see anything. He said when he clicked on Child A’s
name it immediately kicked him off. I asked FCW 3 whether he
attempted to gain access once or more than once. FCW 3
reported believing that he had clicked on Child A’s name twice.
He then stated that he did not know if he had clicked Child A’s
name twice, or his own name twice in MISACWIS. He also stated,
he would not dispute whatever the MISACWIS records shows,
though he denied gaining any information. I asked FCW 3, if he
had been able go further/gain greater access into Child A’s
MISACWIS record would he have. FCW 3 stated “I want to
answer no, but I’m not sure.” FCW 3 stated he was attempting to
obtain information about Child A’s replacement. FCW 3 clarified,
that statement. He stated he and his wife, Foster Parent B knew
Child A was replaced to their respite provider, so there was no
need to look for Child A’s new placement location. He wanted to
know what Wexford/Missaukee DHHS had entered in MISACWIS
as the reason for Child A’s placement change. He did not trust
that Wexford/Missaukee DHHS had put in actual information as to
the reason for Child A’s replacement from his home.
As for what his discipline entailed, FCW 3 reported it was decided
his inappropriate access to MISACWIS was an
employer/employee issue to be handled by his employer (FCW 3
did not indicate who/what entity made that determination or how).
He reported the disciplinary action Holy Cross-MM took with him
in June of 2023 consisted of his supervisor, Supervisor 2
informing him of the allegation, information Holy Cross-MM had
gathered on the matter, and a formal reprimand. FCW 3 said he
was told he was getting a formal reprimand, but he has not seen
that formal reprimand, in writing. He said he was told it was in the
agency’s “Paycor” system, but when he checked that system the
formal reprimand was not there. He said he was told the
reprimand said he violated the agency’s technology policy and
confidentiality policy. The agency told him he could have been
terminated. They also told him the formal reprimand is one level
before termination.
Supervisor 2
On 9/6/2023, I interviewed Supervisor 2 about this allegation by
telephone. Supervisor 2 reported this matter happened months
ago and he and his supervisor, the deputy director, addressed the
matter with FCW 3. He said, FCW 3 admitted to the behavior.
FCW 3 took full responsible for his action. I asked Supervisor 2
5

what FCW 3 reported he did. Supervisor 2 said FCW 3 reported
he attempted to access Child A's MISACWIS record once but
could not get into Child A’s case. FCW 3 told them Child A was a
prior foster child FCW 3 had fostered for two years, but nothing
more. FCW 3 was very remorseful about his actions.
I asked Supervisor 2 what the agency did related to FCW 3’s
inappropriate MISACWIS access behavior. Supervisor 2 said,
about a month and a half ago they reviewed the MISACWIS policy
with FCW 3 and advised FCW 3 he was not to engage in
unauthorized MISACWIS access. Additionally, they entered a
“coaching” disciplinary action into the agency’s Human Resource
(HR) system. Supervisor 2 did not describe this discipline action
as a written reprimand or verbal warning. When I asked him,
where would a verbal coaching action fall with respect to levels of
discipline actions, Supervisor 2 did not know. He reported that
would have to come from their HR department. He reported since
FCW 3’s employment with the agency in December 2022, this
issue has been the only concern reported against FCW 3.
Document Review
Child A’s MISACWIS case record which showed:
• He was placed with FCW 3 and Foster Parent B on
7/1/2021; and replaced to Foster Parents XXs’/his respite
providers on 4/24/2023.
• He was made a Michigan Children’s Institute Ward on
5/24/2023. His permanency plan is adoption.
A MISACWIS Activity Review Log which showed:
• There was no evidence in MISACWIS FCW 3 accessed
Child A’s case record.
• It did show FCW 3 accessed Child A’s person record on
4/18/23 and 5/29/23. Fifteen items were accessed within
the record including health history and address history.
Analysis Based on interviews and documentation reviewed, the evidence
showed FCW 3 made unauthorized access Child A’s MISACWIS
record.
In this instance FCW 3 did not demonstrate responsible and
suitable character related to services to children and families as
would be served by the agency.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED.
6

Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206 Staff Qualification.
Section (2) A staff member must be of responsible character and suitable
Description and able to met the needs of children and families served by the
agency.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation FCW 3, who is also a foster parent, lied under oath at a hearing,
insisting he never requested replacement of Child A; and the
department’s attorney produced written documentation of FCW 3’s
request. There are concerns about the credibility of FCW 3 as he
perjured himself in court as well as misused computer systems to
gain information inappropriately.
Investigation Interviews:
Director X
On 8/21/2023, I interviewed the complainant, Director X, by
telephone. Director X reported on 8/15/2023, FCW 3 testified in
Missaukee County Court at a court hearing for Child A, as a previous
foster parent for Child A foster parent. Director X reported while on
the stand FCW 3 testified that he never requested Child A to be
removed from their home, when FCW 3 had. Director X reported
there was evidence, by way of emails, testified to and submitted
showing that FCW 3 and his wife had requested Child A’s removal
from their home. The judge did not charge FCW 3 with perjury.
Director X explained that Child A had been having respite visits
with another licensed foster family and FCW 3 advised that the
respite family was willing to keep Child A full time. Child A’s
replacement to the respite family ended up occurring.
Chief Administrator 1
On 8/22/2023 I interviewed Holy Cross-MM Chief Administrator
(CA)1 about this allegation by telephone. CA 1 reported when
FCW 3 began his employment with Holy Cross-MM on 12/5/2022,
FCW 3 was already a licensed foster parent with
Wexford/Missaukee DHHS. CA 1 had no information about FCW
3 not being truthful in court or lying on the stand about any case.
She reported that FCW 3 has 10 foster care cases, and she is not
aware of any concern with him testifying as a foster care worker.
FCW 3
On 8/30/2023, I interviewed FCW 3 via TEAMS related to this
complaint. FCW 3 denied the allegation. FCW 3 said, he and
Foster Parent B never asked for Child A’s removal from their
home. He reported the replacement decision for Child A occurred
verbally, but he admitted there is an email from him and Foster
7

Parent B agreeing to Child A being replaced. Despite that email,
FCW 3 said he and Foster Parent B never put in a 30-day request
asking for Child A’s removal. Additionally, they never received a
DHS 30. They had been on the fence about this decision. He said
Child A was having behavior issues and they wanted respite. He
said they asked for Child A’s placement change; but they never
asked for Child A to be removed. He said, Child A’s replacement
deal was between them and the respite provider. That they just
agreed to Child A remaining in placement with the respite
provider. He said 20 hours later they wrote an email to
Wexford/Missaukee DHHS saying they regretted their decision.
He reported, he never lied in court about this. He reported giving
testimony in court about Child A’s replacement as Child A’s prior
foster parent, not as a foster worker on the case. He said the
MISACWIS inappropriate access matter never came up in court.
He reported he was legally advised to indicate that matter was
handled by his employer with disciplinary action. He reported this
complaint is questioning his creditability and his job and he has
never been accused of not being creditable.
Supervisor 2
On 9/6/2023, I interviewed Supervisor 2 by telephone. Supervisor
2 did not have information related to this allegation.
Document Review
Child A’s MISACWIS case record which showed:
• He was placed with FCW 3 and Foster Parent B on
7/1/2021 and replaced to Foster Parents XXs’ home, his
respite providers, on 4/24/2023.
• He was made a Michigan Children’s Institute Ward on
5/24/2023. His permanency plan is adoption.
FCW 3 and Foster Parent B’s CWLM case record which showed:
• They received their original foster home license on
3/23/2021.
• A special evaluation report dated 10/12/2023 related to
allegations the foster parents shared confidential
information about Child A’s case. Additionally, that the
foster parents lied in court when questioned. The special
evaluation found FCW 3 and Foster Parent B in compliance
related to the former allegation and in violation of the foster
home applicant/licensee qualifications rule R400.9201(1)(e)
related to the latter allegation. The special evaluation
concluded FCW 3 was not honest when questioned in
court. A corrective action plan was recommended, and it
was pending.
8

Analysis Based on interviews the evidence showed:
• FCW 3’s testimony in court was that as a foster parent, not
as a worker with responsibility over Child A’s case.
• It is not clear that FCW 3 made deliberate false statement
in court about him and his wife requesting Child A’s
removal, but seemingly made statements in court related
to his perception of how Child A’s removal and
replacement decision came to be. As such his reporting
would not have been perceived as truthful, especially due
to his written statement asking for the child’s replacement.
Additionally, the judge did not find that FCW 3 perjured
himself in court.
• In this instance there is insufficient evidence to support
that FCW 3 did not demonstrate responsible and suitable
character related to services to children and families
served by the agency.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan continuation of the agency’s
current licensing status is recommended.
